더트 레인 24시간
트렐라이 제너럴 굿즈 매장의 오프닝 샷으로 활기찬 곡이 배경에서 연주됩니다.
"당신의 모든 필요를 위해 원스톱 상점을 찾고 있습니까? 트렐라이 잡화만 살펴보십시오!"
그랜드 애비뉴 24hr, 공업 지역, 그리고 다른 많은 장소들.
카메라가 매장의 다양한 구역을 돌아다니며 다양한 상품을 선보입니다.
"우리는 당신의 주말 경기를 위한 스포츠 장비부터 당신의 일상적인 필요를 위한 필수품까지 모든 것을 가지고 있습니다. 그리고 매일 새로운 주식이 도착함에 따라, 항상 발견할 수 있는 신선한 것이 있습니다."
매장을 둘러보는 고객에게 얼굴에 미소를 머금은 채 다양한 물건을 집어 드는 모습으로 자릅니다.
"트렐라이 제너럴 굿즈에서 우리는 최고 수준의 고객 서비스와 양질의 제품을 저렴한 가격에 제공하는 것에 자부심을 가지고 있습니다. 따라서 식료품을 비축하고 있든, 새로운 운동 장비를 찾고 있든, 아니면 독특한 발견을 찾고 있든 간에, 우리는 당신을 보장합니다."
트렐라이 잡화 로고가 눈에 띄게 진열된 매장 마감 사진.
"트렐라이 제너럴 굿즈, 당신의 모든 쇼핑 욕구를 위한 목적지. 오늘 우리를 방문하세요!"
[햇볕 좋은 날 아름다운 집이 보이는 풍경이 펼쳐집니다. 보이스오버가 시작됩니다.]
"당신의 집을 보호하는 것과 관련하여, 당신은 믿을 수 있는 지붕 회사가 필요합니다. 당신은 지붕 래츠 루핑이 필요합니다. 트렐라이의 산업 지역의 더크 레인에 위치한 지붕 래츠 루핑은 1년 넘게 지역 사회를 위해 봉사하고 있습니다."
[루프 래츠 루프의 작업자들이 지붕을 전문적으로 수리하는 팀의 사진을 잘라냅니다.]
"경험이 풍부한 목공 전문가 팀이 지붕을 최상의 상태로 유지하여 누수와 손상으로부터 집을 안전하게 보호할 것입니다."
[새로 수리된 지붕 앞에 서 있는 행복한 고객의 사진을 오려냅니다.]
"물이 새는 지붕이 당신의 하루를 망치게 하지 마세요. 오늘 지붕 래츠 루핑에 전화해서 무료 상담과 견적을 받으세요. 우리의 요금은 경쟁력이 있고 우리의 일은 보장됩니다."
[루프 래츠 루핑' 로고 및 연락처로 절단]
"지붕 쥐 지붕을'. 당신의 지역 지붕 전문가들. 오늘 우리에게 전화하세요."

(sound of helicopter in background)
Man 2: Hello, mam.
Woman: Thank God you’re here! I saw a bug in the kitchen!
Man 2: You did the right thing, mam. We’ll take it from here. Everything’s going to be okay.
(sound of gunfire)

professionals that know how to take care of a messy situation fast.

(sound of zombie gurgiling)
Man 2: Looks like a Pest to me!
(sound of gunshots)
Man 1: Commando Pest Eradication. We kill everything in sight, so you feel safer. It’s the war on nature- and this time, we’re winning.

PROLOGUE - EXT. HOUSE – NIGHT
Lawrence, Kansas... 22 years ago
Crickets chirp. A large deciduous tree with no leaves stands outside one of several suburban homes.
INT. NURSERY – NIGHT
A WOMAN, MARY WINCHESTER, wearing a white nightgown, carries a SMALL CHILD, her son DEAN, into a dark room.
MARY: Come on, let's say good night to your brother.

MARY turns on the lights: it's the nursery of a BABY, SAM, who is lying in his crib and looking over at MARY and DEAN. MARY sets DEAN down. DEAN leans over the side of the crib and kisses SAM on the forehead.
DEAN:' Night, Sam.
MARY leans over SAM as well.
MARY: Good night, love.
MARY brushes SAM's hair back and kisses his forehead.
MAN: Hey, Dean.
DEAN turns. The MAN in the doorway wearing a USMC T-shirt is JOHN. DEAN rushes over to him.
DEAN: Daddy!
JOHN: Hey, Buddy.
JOHN scoops DEAN up.
JOHN: So what do you think? You think Sammy's ready to toss around a football yet?
DEAN shakes his head, laughing.
DEAN: No, Daddy.
JOHN laughs.
JOHN: No.
MARY passes JOHN and DEAN on the way out of the room.
MARY: You got him?
JOHN: I got him.
JOHN hugs DEAN closer.
JOHN: Sweet dreams, Sam.
JOHN carries DEAN out of the room, flipping off the lights. SAM watches them go, gurgling, then tries to reach his toes.
The baseball-themed mobile above SAM's crib begins to spin on its own while SAM watches. The transportation-themed clock on the wall ticks, ticks, stops. The moon-shaped nightlight flickers.
INT. MASTER BEDROOM – NIGHT
<static>

Lights flicker on a baby monitor sitting on a nightstand next to a photo of MARY and JOHN. Strange noises come through the monitor. MARY, asleep in bed, stirs. She turns on the light on the nightstand.
MARY: John?
MARY turns: she's alone. She gets up.
INT. HALLWAY – NIGHT
MARY walks down the hall to SAM's nursery. JOHN, seen only in silhouette, stands over SAM's crib.
MARY: John? Is he hungry?
JOHN turns his head.
MAN: Shhhhh.
MARY: All right.
MARY heads back down the hallway. The light by the stairs is flickering. MARY frowns and goes to tap at it till the light steadies.
MARY: Hm.

More flickering light is coming from downstairs: MARY investigates. A war movie is on TV and JOHN has fallen asleep watching it. If JOHN is here, MARY realizes, then the MAN upstairs cannot be JOHN and must be a danger. She runs back upstairs.
MARY: Sammy, Sammy!
MARY enters SAM's nursery and stops short.
INT. LIVING ROOM – NIGHT
Upstairs, MARY screams. JOHN wakes up.
JOHN: Mary?
JOHN scrambles out of the chair.
JOHN: Mary!
JOHN runs upstairs.
INT. NURSERY – NIGHT
JOHN bursts through the closed door of the nursery.
JOHN: Mary.
The room is quiet and appears empty except for SAM awake in his crib and JOHN. JOHN glances around and pushes down the side of SAM's crib.
JOHN: Hey, Sammy. You okay?

Something dark drips next to SAM. JOHN touches it. Two more drops land on the back of JOHN's hand. It looks like blood. JOHN looks up. MARY is sprawled across the ceiling, the stomach of her nightgown red with blood, staring at JOHN and struggling to breathe. JOHN collapses onto the floor, staring at MARY.
JOHN: No! Mary!
MARY bursts into flame. The fire spreads over the ceiling. JOHN stares, frozen. SAM wails. JOHN, reminded he's not alone, gets up and scoops SAM out of his crib and rushes out of the room.
INT. HALLWAY – NIGHT
DEAN is awake and coming to investigate.
DEAN: Daddy!
JOHN shoves SAM at DEAN.
JOHN: Take your brother outside as fast as you can and don't look back! Now, Dean, go!
DEAN turns and runs. JOHN turns back to the nursery.
JOHN: Mary!
The entire room is on fire. MARY herself can barely be seen.
JOHN: No!
EXT. HOUSE – NIGHT
DEAN runs outside, holding SAM.
DEAN: It's okay, Sammy.
DEAN turns to look up at SAM's window, which is lit with gold.
JOHN runs outside, scoops up DEAN and SAM, and carries them both away.
JOHN: I gotcha.
Fire explodes out of SAM's nursery window.
EXT. HOUSE – NIGHT, LATER
The Lawrence fire department has arrived. A FIREFIGHTER gets out of a fire truck and takes over at the gauges for another firefighter.
FIREFIGHTER: I got it. You go hold the line up.

The second firefighter goes to the back of the truck and takes a hose from a third firefighter. That firefighter takes the hose towards the house where a fourth firefighter is spraying through SAM's nursery window. A paramedic opens the back of an ambulance. A POLICE OFFICER waves some neighbors back.
OFFICER: Stay back. You have to stay back.
Across the street from the house, JOHN and DEAN sit on the hood of JOHN's Impala, JOHN holding SAM. JOHN looks up at the remnants of the fire.
"Gasoline" by Ginger begins to play.
To be Concluded.
In a hardware shop. Ronnie Corbett is behind the counter, wearing a warehouse jacket. He has just finished serving a customer.
CORBETT (muttering): There you are. Mind how you go.
(Ronnie Barker enters the shop, wearing a scruffy tank-top and beanie)
BARKER: Four Candles!
CORBETT: Four Candles?
BARKER: Four Candles.
(Ronnie Corbett makes for a box, and gets out four candles. He places them on the counter)
BARKER: No, four candles!
CORBETT (confused): Well there you are, four candles!
BARKER: No, fork 'andles! 'Andles for forks!
(Ronnie Corbett puts the candles away, and goes to get a fork handle. He places it onto the counter)
CORBETT (muttering): Fork handles. Thought you said 'four candles!' (more clearly)
Next!
<static>
BARKER: Got any plugs?
CORBETT: Plugs. What kind of plugs?
BARKER: A rubber one, bathroom.
(Ronnie Corbett gets out a box of bath plugs, and places it on the counter)
CORBETT (pulling out two different sized plugs): What size?
BARKER: Thirteen amp!
CORBETT (muttering): It's electric bathroom plugs, we call them, in the trade. Electric bathroom plugs!
(He puts the box away, gets out another box, and places on the counter an electric plug, then puts the box away)
BARKER: Saw tips!
CORBETT: Saw tips? (he doesn't know what he means) What d'you want? Ointment, or something like that?
BARKER: No, saw tips for covering saws.
CORBETT: Oh, haven't got any, haven't got any. (he mutters) Comin' in, but we haven' got any. Next?
BARKER: 'O's!
BARKER: 'O's!
BARKER: 'O's.
(He goes to get a hoe, and places it on the counter)
BARKER: No, 'O's!
CORBETT: 'O's! I thought you said 'O! (he takes the hose back, and gets a hose, whilst muttering) When you said 'O's, I thought you said 'O! 'O's!
(He places the hose onto the counter)
BARKER: No, 'O's!
CORBETT (confused for a moment): O's? Oh, you mean panty 'o's, panty 'o's! (he picks up a pair of tights from beside him)
BARKER: No, no, 'O's! 'O's for the gate. Mon repose! 'O's! Letter O's!
CORBETT (finally realising): Letter O's! (muttering) You had me going there!
(He climbs up a stepladder, gets a box down, puts the ladder away, and takes the box to the counter, and searches through it for letter O's)
CORBETT: How many d'you want?
BARKER: Two.

(Ronnie Corbett leaves two letter O's on the counter, then takes the box back, gets the ladder out again, puts the box away, climbs down the ladder, and puts the ladder away, then returns to the counter)
CORBETT: Yes, next?
BARKER: Got any P's?
CORBETT (fed up): For Gawd' sake, why didn' you bleedin' tell me that while I was up there then? I'm up and down the shop already, it's up and down the bleedin' shop all the time.
(He gets the ladder out, climbs up and gets the box of letters down, then puts the ladder away)
Honestly, I've got all this shop, I ain't got any help, it's worth it we plan things. (He puts the box on the counter, and gets out some letter P's) How many d'you want?
BARKER: No! Tins of peas. Three tins of peas!
CORBETT: You're 'avin' me on, ain't ya, yer 'avin' me on?
BARKER: I'm not!
(Ronnie Corbett dumps the box under the counter, and gets three tins of peas)
CORBETT (placing the tins on the counter): Next?
BARKER: Got any pumps?
CORBETT (getting really fed up): 'And pumps, foot pumps? Come on!
BARKER (surprised he has to ask): Foot pumps!
CORBETT (muttering, as he goes down the shop): Foot pumps. See a foot pump? (He sees one, and picks it up) Tidy up in 'ere.
(He puts the pump down on the counter)
BARKER: No, pumps fer ya feet! Brown pump, size nine!
CORBETT (almost at breaking point): You are 'avin' me on, you are definitely 'avin' me on!
BARKER (not taking much notice of Corbett's mood): I'm not!
CORBETT: You are 'avin' me on! (He takes back the pump, and gets a pair of brown foot pumps out of a drawer, and places them on the counter) Next?
BARKER: Washers!

Ron Chester was born on July 21st 1955, was a person who had ambition to purse a career on journalism during his early years in High school. He went To Bradford high and managed to barely graduate! However, he was quite a "party animal."
He would go into nightclubs and show off his dance moves, like the crazy guy he was back in the late 70s. But during the 80s he decided to grow up and begin his dream on becoming a newscaster.
Graduating out of LSU with a bachelors on journalism. Unfortunately that path didn't go out so well. With him barely starting his journey with his dream career, The outbreak began..
Ron was working at the WBLN News station in Downtown Louisville when it happened, the man barely escaped out of the station alive with a couple of others, but soon to be separated with the others,
becoming a man alone in this fucked up world. At this point, it was either him or them. And he wasn't going out that way.
**TRIBUTES**

Hayden parkinson was born into a family of 5. He was looking to become a games tester because of his love for games but he decided to be more realistic and pursue a career in IT. Due to his love of video games he never got out much and didnt have many friends. Which is one of the main reasons why he survived the outbreak
and his family did not. He had no one to lookout for but himself after his family got bit and had to put them down. He has been on his own ever since.
He may not very good with a weapon but he's quieter and sneaker than most normal people. But he's willing to learn anything it takes to survive this nightmare.
**TRIBUTES**

A Simple Man Flawed and gifted in everyway, Just Wanted to Live a Normal Life, But got involved with Criminals. Dabbled in Burglary in his youth and getting into trouble with the law, drug dealing to his local community as the local stoner.

Worked as a Bouncer for a local nightclub, Don't get behind his baseball bat as he was the home run king as a baseball player for the towns team. Insanely Fit and Drives fast. Always Thirsty and always Hungry,
Always wanting more, The Apocalypse hit while he was asleep, and was the only man to come out of his street alive, covered in blood.

He's Trying to resettle and build a local community, Some would say he took to the apocalypse a bit to much and hosts a local radio station @ 100mhz with Various Zombie Themed Music, For the pleasure of the Surviving Citizens,
as well as searching for survivors, The Man will not go down, without a fight to the bitter end.
**TRIBUTES**
Elaine is your casual friendly Canadian girl. She used to be a teacher, before those devilish creatures swarmed the world coming through hell's gates.

She grew up in a humble and religious family, and she loved going to the church every sunday with her parents. Elaine used to have a little sister named Katy with whom she loved playing hide and seek in their backyard.
One day, while they were playing catch together, Katy ran over the road and at that moment..
a car they didn't notice was speeding on the road. Those few seconds Elaine had to witness her sister's death felt like ages to her.
This traumatized her enough that to this day she still feels highly uncomfortable in cars and she has never dared driving a car.
**TRIBUTES**
Ulysses Hendrix 6'2 A male with milk chocolate skin, dark brown, almost black eyes and dull black hair in cornrows, including a full beard
appears to be a rugged, renaissance man whom people respect. But alas, he is putting on this act to cope with the lack of affection and prominent bullying he dealt with growing up.
Beneath the bulk and ability of this man still lies the lanky boy who had a interest in engineering, and who paid for that with interest in the form of relentless teasing and psychological abuse.
Well, he thought, he’ll just bulk up and do ‘real man’s work’ like carpentry and electrical. And wouldn’t you know it, he started to gain respect from his peers! But, it left him hollow.

How could he trust people when he’d seen what evil they’re capable of towards those they don’t approve of. So now, Ulysses is wary of others, and uses his varied skills to keep himself safe as he makes his way in this new world.

Edgar is a boy who was born in Mexico, raised in a remote village in the lush forests of Monte Bello, but that would not last long as his parents emigrated to Kentucky when he was four years old.
from a young age he enjoyed sports and especially extreme sports, such as rock climbing and skateboarding down the roads of Rosewood,
standing out in his academic years for his athleticism and bravery. This path opened up several opportunities for him when he finished his studies,
one of them being a scholarship as an athlete or another more in line with his taste for adrenaline as a firefighter,
which he ended up choosing. That job was made for him and he performed well along with all his colleagues in all services and forest fires,
making many friends due to his jovial and risky character. When the infected took over Knox County, despite the losses and sadness for his future and family, Paddy decided to take it as a challenge.

"But now that I'm done with that, I'm gonna catch some shut-eye. Don't worry, though, the radio will still be on. You never know when we might get some important news or just need to chat with each other. Stay safe out there, folks. Bigz out."
With that, the radio transmission ends, leaving the listeners to continue their day with Bigz's words ringing in their ears.
[Static on the airwaves]
[Radio static fades out]
[Opening music and sound effects]

Announcer: "Hello? Anyone out there? This is The Announcer, broadcasting from our small community in Trelai. We haven't heard from Bigz in over 24 hours. If anyone has any information on his whereabouts, please let us know."
[Silence]

Announcer: "We're starting to get worried here. Bigz never misses a show, and he's been a vital member of our community. We have reason to believe that he may have gone out on a scouting mission, but we're not sure."
[Radio static]

The Announcer's voice sounded worried as he spoke into the microphone, "This is The Announcer, coming to you live from the Trelai radio station. We're coming up on 24 hours of radio silence from Bigz and the bunker. We're all hoping they're just dealing with some technical difficulties or something, but we can't help but feel concerned."
He took a deep breath before continuing,

"I'm sure many of you out there are feeling the same way. We've all grown accustomed to hearing Bigz's voice at noon every day, and it's been a source of comfort for many of us during these trying times."
The Announcer paused for a moment, collecting his thoughts before he spoke again,

"We don't know what's happened to Bigz and the bunker, but we're not giving up hope. They're survivors, and they've made it this far. We have to believe that they'll pull through whatever they're dealing with and come back to us."
He leaned closer to the microphone, his voice lowering to a whisper,
"But just in case they're listening, Bigz, if you can hear me, we're all here for you. Whatever's going on, we'll get through it together. Stay strong, my friend."
The Announcer sat back in his chair, a sense of unease settling over him as he waited for any kind of response. The silence on the other end was deafening.

The Philosopher. AW.

Nature is like a musical expression, which means exactly what it says. Giraffes are giraffing, trees are treeing, stars are starring, clouds are clouding. Rain is raining. And if you don’t understand, look at it again. And people are peopleing.

We notice that all these ‘suchnesses’ appear and disappear. They keep changing, they come and they go. But if you get hung up on your particular form—I’ll have to alter the language a little bit because, you see, “your form” makes a duality.
Whereas you are your form. You’re what you’re doing. Now, you think, “Hmm. For some strange reason I must make that go on as long as possible.”
And therefore you think you have an instinct to survive. And so the only thing anybody can agree about today, so far as the discussion of ethical and moral problems are concerned,
is that we ought to survive. And therefore, certain forms of conduct have survival value and certain forms don’t.
But when you say to yourself you must go on living, you put yourself in a double-bind. Because you’ve said to a process—which is essentially spontaneous—that it must happen.

you are required to do that which will be acceptable only if you do it voluntarily. So when we say to ourselves “you must go on,” the reason is, you see, that we are not living in the eternal now, where reality is.

We are always thinking that the satisfaction of life will be coming later. “There’s a good time coming, be it ever so far away.” That one far-off, divine event to which all creation moves. Don’t kid yourself.
in the course of time everything gets worse. It eventually falls apart.
Which is to say, only suckers put hope in the future.

How to with Paulie (3/4)

Welcome to How To with Paulie! Today, I want to share with you the art of foraging. Now, I know what you might be thinking, "Foraging? What's that?" But trust me, with a little bit of knowledge, you can find useful resources just lying around on the ground.

Start by standing still and taking a closer look at your surroundings. You'll find sticks and stones at first, but soon enough you'll become a master at finding berries, mushrooms, wild fruits, and plants. You can even find insects and animals that can be used for food or medicinal purposes.

Some of you might think that foraging isn't very useful, but let me tell you, all you need is a tree branch, a stone, and a rag, and you've got yourself a hammer. Sharpen that stone, and you can make a knife! It all depends on where you search. Look in the trees, bushes, roads, and even inner cities. You'll be amazed at what you can find.

So, join me on this journey of discovery as we learn how to forage for that good stuff. With a little bit of patience and practice, you can become a master forager and find the resources you need to survive in this world.

High Time with Buddy and the Pup: Pup's Day Out (3/10)
Buddy and Pup are lounging on the couch, enjoying a bowl of their favorite strain, when Pup suddenly jumps up and starts barking excitedly at the door.
Buddy: "What's up, Pup? You want to go out?"
Pup barks again, and Buddy gets the hint. He puts on his shoes and grabs the leash, and they head out for a walk.
As they're strolling through the park, Buddy gets so high that he suddenly realizes he can understand Pup's barks in perfect English.
Pup: "Finally, you're getting it. Now, let me show you around."
Buddy is stunned, but he goes along with it, and Pup leads him to all of his favorite spots in the park.
Pup: "This is where I like to chase squirrels. And this is where I like to roll in the grass. And over there is my favorite spot to pee."
Buddy can't stop laughing, and he starts to realize that Pup has a real sense of humor.
Pup: "You know, Buddy, I don't think I've ever seen you this high before. It's like you're on my level now."
Buddy: "I know, man. It's crazy. I feel like we're communicating on a whole different level."
Pup: "Exactly. And that's why I brought you here. I wanted you to see the world from my perspective. You humans are always so serious. You need to lighten up and enjoy life a little more."
Buddy: "You're right, Pup. I think I've been taking things too seriously lately. I need to relax and have some fun."
Pup: "That's the spirit, Buddy. Now let's go get some snacks and keep this good vibe going."
They head to the convenience store, and Buddy is amazed when Pup orders a bag of dog treats in perfect English.
Buddy: "Dude, you're blowing my mind right now."
Pup: "Hey, I've been practicing my English for a long time. It's nice to finally be able to use it with you."
Buddy and Pup sit outside the store, munching on treats and enjoying the sunshine. For a moment, they forget all their worries and just enjoy each other's company.
As they head back home, Buddy realizes that this is what life is all about: having fun, enjoying the little things, and being with the ones you love.
Buddy: "Thanks for showing me the ropes, Pup. I don't know what I'd do without you."
Pup: "Anytime, Bud. That's what I'm here for."

Buddy and Pup are sitting on their apartment window, smoking a joint. When Suddenly the power goes out.

Buddy jumps up from the couch, energized.

Buddy heads over to his computer and starts searching for marathon training plans.

Woof woof Woof?

Maybe we should slow down a bit, Pup.
Pup looks back at Buddy, concerned.
Woof woof.
Buddy ignores Pup and continues to push himself, determined to prove his point.

Buddy and his dog, Pup, are sitting on the couch, surrounded by empty food containers and pizza boxes. Buddy looks at Pup.
BUDDY: (smiling) What do you say, Pup? Time to restock the fridge?

Buddy and Pup are walking through the aisles of the grocery store. Pup is sniffing everything in sight while Buddy is picking out items from the shelves.

BUDDY: (to Pup) Hold up, Pup. Check out that fine lady.

BUDDY: You know, Pup, I think you have a real gift for sniffing out trouble.

Buddy and Pup make their way back home, ready to enjoy their freshly stocked fridge and keep an eye out for any potential trouble.

The camera is pointed at Buddy and his dog, Pup, as they are lounging on the couch, smoking a joint.
BUDDY(laughing) I’m telling you, Pup, if we ever want to make it big in the apocalypse, we’ve got to diversify our talents.

BUDDY(surprised) Oh, hey there.
JESSICA:(smiling)
BUDDY(nervously) Hey Thanks for the other day, Come on in.
Jessica enters the room and sits down on the couch next to Buddy.

Jessica lunges at Buddy, revealing that she has turned into a zombie.

Buddy and Pup run out of the apartment, chased by the zombified Jessica.

The Philosopher's Struggle

The sound of footsteps echoes through the empty house as a lone survivor, a PHILOSOPHER, makes his way through the debris. He stops in a room, sets down his backpack, and takes out a notebook and a pen.
PHILOSOPHER: I have always been a philosopher. It used to be my job to think about the meaning of life and the purpose of existence. Now, all I can think about is survival.
The philosopher starts writing in his notebook as he speaks.

What is the point of living in this world, where death lurks around every corner? Is it worth it to keep fighting for survival when the odds are so clearly stacked against us? These are the questions that haunt me every day.
Suddenly, the sound of footsteps outside the room interrupts the philosopher's thoughts. He quickly puts away his notebook and takes out a knife.
PHILOSOPHER: Survival comes first.
The door bursts open and a group of zombies enter the room. The philosopher fights them off with his knife, but one of them manages to bite him before he kills it.

PHILOSOPHER: As I feel my strength leaving me, I wonder if it was all for nothing. Did my years of philosophical musings mean anything in this new world? Or was it all just meaningless ramblings of a man who had no idea what the real world was like?

The philosopher falls to the ground, surrounded by the dead bodies of the zombies he fought off. He takes out his notebook and starts writing again, struggling to hold on to his thoughts as he feels himself slipping away.

PHILOSOPHER: Maybe the answer to the meaning of life is not something we can find in a book or in our thoughts. Maybe it's simply the will to survive. The will to keep fighting, even when all hope seems lost.
The philosopher's hand falls to the ground, the pen and notebook slipping out of his grasp. The camera pans out to show his lifeless body, surrounded by the carnage of the zombie apocalypse.
Fade to black.
